name: Dr KT Achaya: Life, Legacy and Passions
description:
Who was Dr K.T. Achaya?

Join Vinod Huria as he explores the life and legacy of Dr K.T. Achaya. As a former student of Dr Achaya, Vinod Huria presents a personal account of the scientist who pioneered research and writing on Indian foods. Learn of the many achievements and contributions that Dr Achaya has made to Indian food science, from his work in oil production to his research into food and nutrition. Discover how his books introduced new ways of writing and thinking about food writing in India.

This lecture is part of our launch of an exhibit on KT Achaya’s life as part of CALORIE.

name: Tiny Chefs, Big Impact: Fermentation and the Future of Gut Health
description:
How do bacteria and yeasts turn everyday foods into flavours that nourish your gut, your immunity, and your mood?

Join Pooja Dewan as she enters the microscopic kitchen and explores the science of fermentation. Watch microbes transform simple ingredients into fizzy, tangy, gut-loving foods; taste and sip fermentation in action; and discover how your gut microbiome powers energy, immunity, and wellbeing. You’ll even get hands-on by creating your own mini ferment to take home.

name: Create, Consume, Discard : Eating in the Age of Plastics
description:
From packaging to clothes and now even in our food; plastics have found a ‘home’ everywhere. 

Despite growing concerns about its disposal starting as early as the 1960s, plastic production and use are only projected to grow. We know today that plastics are not only harmful in their everlasting afterlives but also in use - leaching millions of microplastics into food and water with every use. While reliance on plastics is a marker of living in the 21st century, how do we balance overconsumption and necessity? Join our Experimentor Ayati for this walkthrough as we attempt to look at the life-cycle of plastics and their role in our food systems through the CALORIE exhibition.

name: Rage Against the Machine: Understanding Bias in Computer Vision Algorithms
description:
What biases shape how machines see the world, and how can our conscious choices help make them more empathetic?

Rage Against the Machine is a playful critique of the biases embedded in computer vision algorithms, and an invitation to reflect on how conscious human choices can help build more empathetic machines. Join CALORIE artist Sahitya Papireddy as she uses Teachable Machine, a graphical and user-friendly tool for training machine-learning models. Participants will learn how to “feed” a model with images to help it identify a cup, explore how a machine defines what a cup is—and what it isn’t—and then attempt to “break” the model by uncovering loopholes in its detection system. Through this process, the session reveals how machines see the world, and how this perception can be surprisingly different from human vision.

The participants need to carry their own laptop that has a camera as well as a cup/mug of their choice.

name: Will You Join Me For Lunch?: The Rise and Fall (and Rise) of Commensality
description:
"Commensality", derived from the Latin words 'com' (with) and 'mensa' (table), refers to the practice of eating together at the same table.

In this talk—more a conversation than a lecture—CALORIE artist Sahitya explores the deep connection between food and human relationships and how the act of eating together has evolved over time. She reflects on what transforms eating from a mere task into a shared experience, drawing on the idea that “we are not only what we eat, but also who we eat with” — Harry G. West.

name: Tangible Selfies: Materialising Personal Data
description:
What if we could reflect on data about ourselves, not through charts and apps but with tangible materials?

In this workshop, Rasagy Sharma will explore personal data through the lens of quantified self-practices and tangible data representation. In a world obsessed with big data, large data models and digital automation, this workshop invites you to slow down and observe your daily lives with intention and curiosity. Participants will explore how to curate and make physical artefacts with their data. 

Whether you maintain detailed journals, use digital tracking apps, or are just curious to visualise a new year’s resolution, you’ll leave with a new perspective about data and its representation.

name: The Making of an Exhibition: Women of Mathematics
description:
How is a portrait exhibition created, and how can it foreground the human side of mathematics?

Join photographer Noel Tovia Matoff, mathematician Sylvie Paycha, and physicist Sumati Surya for a panel discussion on the making of the upcoming exhibition Women of Mathematics. Bringing together photographic portraits and personal narratives of women mathematicians from around the world, the exhibition explores the lives, work, and intellectual journeys that shape the production of mathematics across different contexts. This discussion will unpack the process behind creating the portraits, how the women’s experiences were documented, and how storytelling informed the exhibition’s curatorial approach. The panel will reflect on how mathematics is produced by people rather than abstractions, and how attention to lived experience can make visible the institutional, cultural, and systemic conditions that shape participation in the field.
